clinical_study.brief_title: A Clinical Trial Comparing Isolite® vs. Cotton Roll Isolation in the Placement of Dental Sealants
clinical_study.official_title: A Clinical Trial Comparing Isolite® vs Cotton Roll Isolation in the Placement of Dental Sealants

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this split-mouth, randomized, controlled trial is to evaluate the retention rates of sealants placed under Isolite vs. cotton roll isolation. This study will also compare the patient and operator acceptability and satisfaction of the two isolation techniques as well as the time consumed for sealant application during the two isolation techniques.

detailed_description.textblock: 100 regular patients at the College of Dentistry Department of Pediatric Dentistry Clinics, ages 6-16 years, will be invited to participate in this study. Matched contralateral pairs of first and second molars and premolars will be randomized to receive sealants with the use of the deice (Isolite) for isolation or with the use of cotton roll isolation. All sealants will be placed by pediatric dentistry residents. Sealants will be placed on first and second permanent molars that have a matched contralateral molar requiring a sealant as well. Photographs may be taken of the sealants on the day of placement and at a 6-month and 12 month recalls. Retention of the sealants will be evaluated and scored by calibrated pediatric dentists.

study_design_info.masking_description: It is a double blinded trial. participants and outcome assessors do not know the randomization. However, it was hard to blind the care provider.

primary_outcome.measure: Categorical scale of Sealant retention by direct examination
primary_outcome.description: Physical examination will be done and recorded as completely retained, partially retained not at risk for dental caries, partially retained and at risk for caries development or completely lost. Recordings will be done for each application site of the sealants. For each of the surfaces sealed in the teeth. Upper molars will have 3 recorded sites (mesioclusal, distoclusal and palatal), lower molars will have two recorded sites (occlusal and buccal) and upper and lower premolars will have one recorded site (occlusal). Teeth of 100 child participants will be evaluated.

secondary_outcome.measure: Categorical scale of Marginal adaptation of the dental sealant by direct examination
secondary_outcome.description: Direct clinical examination will be done and marginal adaptation will be recorded as good or poor for each of the surfaces sealed in the teeth. Upper molars will have 3 recorded sites (mesiocclusal, distocclusal and palatal), lower molars will have two recorded sites (occlusal and buccal) and upper and lower premolars will have one recorded site (occlusal). Teeth of 100 child participants will be evaluated.

secondary_outcome.measure: Categorical scale for the presence of dental caries by direct examination and radiographic examination if necessary
secondary_outcome.description: Clinical examination will be completed and documented if yes there are caries or no there are not caries for each of the surfaces sealed in the teeth. Upper molars will have 3 recorded sites (mesiocclusal, distocclusal and palatal), lower molars will have two recorded sites (occlusal and buccal) and upper and lower premolars will have one recorded site (occlusal). Teeth of 100 child participants will be evaluated.

secondary_outcome.measure: Categorical scale of child satisfaction with the isolation technique by direct reporting
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At the time of placement of the sealants
secondary_outcome.description: The child will be asked to answer several questions related to the convenience of the procedure and the preference of the isolation method used. Direct interviewing of the child exactly after the placement of the sealant will be carried out and the answers are closed ended (yes, no) or which procedure/ device did you prefer.

secondary_outcome.measure: Categorical scale of provider satisfaction with the isolation technique and its relation to the patient behavior
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At the time of placement of the sealants
secondary_outcome.description: The provider (pediatric dentistry resident) will be asked to answer several questions related to the convenience of the procedure and the preference of the isolation method used.

secondary_outcome.measure: Numerical scale of the time used to place the sealants
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At the time of sealant placement
secondary_outcome.description: The time for sealant placement for each side will be compared for the two isolation methods used.

clinical_study.condition: Dental Caries on Pit and Fissure Surface

arm_group.description: The Isolite® technique differs in that it utilizes a flexible plastic dental adapter to separate the teeth from the cheek and tongue. The resident dentist will show the child the Isolite® before it is placed in the mouth. The resident with whom the child is scheduled will then apply the sealants.
The resident dentist with whom the child is scheduled with apply the sealants after the cotton roll technique has been placed.

intervention.description: The Isolite technique utilizes a flexible plastic dental adapter to separate the cheek and tongue prior to sealant application.
A cotton roll is placed between the cheek and tongue prior to sealant application

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Healthy patients: American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) I or II
- Good cooperation: Frank1 3 or 4
- Aged between 6-16 years old at the day of sealant placement
- Minimum of two, maximum of sixteen, matched contralateral permanent molars or premolars.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Teeth with a history of past or current caries
- Teeth with a linical presentation of fluorosis, hypoplasia or any developmental anomalies
- Teeth with clinical or radiographic evidence of pathology
- Teeth with a history of restoration or sealant
- Patients who are poorly behaved
